newsitem.title: USA: Micron says chip prices edged higher in Q3.
newsitem.headline: Micron says chip prices edged higher in Q3.

text.p: Micron Technology Inc on Wednesday said average selling prices for its computer memory chips had improved slightly in its fiscal third quarter compared with the previous three months.

"For our third quarter we saw a very modest improvement in (average selling prices) as compared to second quarter," said Wilbur Stover, Micron's chief financial officer. The company's third quarter ended last week.
He said memory chip prices had also shown some stability during the first and second quarters.
But he told a Paine Webber conference in New York that Micron had budgeted for a five to six percent decline annually in selling prices over the next year and a half.
"We are anticipating a decline in price for the next several years," Stover said. "But what we see on the horizon is a pretty strong picture for PC demand."
Spot prices for memory chips were five to 10 percent lower at the end of May than at the beginning of the month, he said.
Stover said Micron likely showed some modest increases in its units of finished goods in the third quarter, but he said he was not uncomfortable with the company's inventory level.
"Given our pricing sense today, there is less risk of downside pressure, so there is less reason to push our inventory out the door," he said.
Micron also said it was not seeing signs of a slowdown in personal computer demand, a concern that has spooked the market recently.
"We have listened with great interest to announcements this week which have suggested demand has slowed....This is inconsistent with our experience," Stover said.
He said: "We're still seeing strong increases in the amount of memory which is being taken by our key (customers), relative to their contractual agreements with us."
With prices up, Micron could show higher gross margins in the third quarter than in the second quarter, Stover said.
The company's semiconducctor operations recorded a gross margin of 32 percent in the second quarter, an improvement from 24 percent in the first quarter, Stover said.

"Micron has been and continues to be pleased by its position as it rides out this downcycle," Stover said. "We've been able to push our costs down even lower than our competition, so once again we have been able to enjoy profitability even in this downcycle."
But the percentage increase in production during the third quarter would likely be only be half as large as they were in the second and first quarters, he said.
Production increased 55 percent from the first quarter to the second quarter, Stover said.
